source_file: THINGS WE LOST IN THE FIRE.pdf

metadata.filename: THINGS WE LOST IN THE FIRE.pdf

analysis.title: Things We Lost in the Fire
analysis.author: Allan Loeb
analysis.logline: After her husband's tragic death, a widow invites his heroin-addicted best friend to live with her family, leading to an unlikely healing journey for all.

hook_clarity.note: Widow invites dead husband's junkie friend to live with family - clear pitch

audience_targeting.note: Adult drama audience, similar to Babel/Crash

freshness.note: Grief + addiction combo feels familiar but specific dynamic is fresh

execution_independence.note: Strong concept works even with mediocre execution

concept.justification: Pages 55-57: The central concept crystallizes when Audrey invites Jerry to live above the garage - an unlikely pairing that creates inherent dramatic tension and opportunity for mutual healing
page_citations: Page 57: Audrey offers Jerry the garage apartment
Page 48: Jerry meets the children at funeral
concept.weakness_identified: Concept feels somewhat familiar in addiction/grief drama space

act_architecture.note: Clear three acts but transitions feel soft

scene_necessity.note: Most scenes serve character development effectively

momentum.note: Middle section drags during recovery period

payoff_delivery.note: Emotional payoffs work but structural ones less clear

structure.justification: Act breaks at death (page 27), Jerry moving in (page 57), and relapse/recovery (page 96). Structure serves character over plot.
page_citations: Page 96: Jerry's relapse begins final act
structure.weakness_identified: Second act lacks clear dramatic progression

goal_clarity.note: Audrey's goals are emotional/internal, less clear externally

active_agency.note: She makes key decisions but often reactive

arc_credibility.note: From frozen grief to emotional breakthrough feels earned

star_vehicle_quality.note: Complex widow role would attract major actresses

protagonist.justification: Audrey's journey from emotional numbness to breaking down crying is well-tracked, though her goals remain largely internal
page_citations: Page 110: Audrey finally cries - major character breakthrough

character_distinction.note: Jerry, Harper, Dory all have distinct voices and personalities

functional_purpose.note: Each character serves story while remaining interesting

castability.note: Jerry especially is a strong character actor showcase

supporting_cast.justification: Jerry is fully realized with clear arc from addiction to recovery. Children feel authentic, not precocious.
page_citations: Page 75: Dory putting head underwater - Jerry's breakthrough with children
Page 66: Kelly F's share at NA meeting shows depth
supporting_cast.weakness_identified: Some supporting characters like Howard feel underdeveloped

voice_distinction.note: Characters have distinct speech patterns, especially Jerry vs Audrey

subtext_quality.note: Some good subtext but also direct exposition

translation_quality.note: Dialogue would translate well, universal themes

dialogue.justification: Natural, character-specific dialogue but lacks memorable quotes
page_citations: Page 64: 'It should've been you, Jerry' - brutal honesty

obligatory_scenes.note: Grief stages, addiction struggles, family healing all present

emotional_delivery.note: Genuine emotional impact in key scenes

convention_innovation.note: Fresh take on familiar grief/addiction territory

genre_execution.justification: Strong execution of grief drama conventions with authentic addiction portrayal
page_citations: Page 110-111: Audrey's emotional breakdown - powerful cathartic moment

voice_distinctiveness.note: Competent voice but not highly distinctive

premise_novelty.note: Specific dynamic of widow/junkie friend is fresh

cultural_freshness.note: Universal themes but Seattle setting feels authentic

originality.justification: Fresh take on grief through addiction lens, but execution is conventional
page_citations: Page 82: Jerry teaching Dory to swim - unexpected father figure dynamics

cultural_resonance.rationale: Universal themes of family, grief, addiction translate perfectly. Strong family bonds central to story align with LatAm values

regional_casting_potential.rationale: Roles could work with Gael García Bernal as Jerry, Salma Hayek or Cecilia Suárez as Audrey. Universal character types

theatrical_appeal.rationale: Intimate drama better suited for streaming but emotional catharsis could work theatrically

marketing_viability.rationale: Challenging to market - no clear hook beyond cast. Relies on word-of-mouth

coproduction_potential.rationale: Very American setting and context, limited coproduction appeal

major_weaknesses: Conventional execution doesn't match premise originality

target_audience.note: Adult drama audience exists but limited

marketing_hook.note: No clear marketing angle beyond cast

budget_return_ratio.note: Low budget but limited upside potential

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Act 1 ends page 27 (Brian's death), Act 2 ends page 96 (Jerry's relapse), Act 3 resolution
structure_analysis.pacing: Strong opening, saggy middle during recovery period, emotional climax works

characters.protagonist: Audrey Burke - grieving widow, emotionally frozen, goal is healing though not clearly articulated
characters.antagonist: Addiction itself, grief, internal obstacles rather than human antagonist
supporting: Jerry Sunborne - complex addict with genuine friendship bond
Harper - precocious but not annoying daughter

standout_scenes.scene: Jerry teaches Dory to swim underwater
standout_scenes.why: Emotional breakthrough that belonged to dead father
Cathartic release of grief, story's emotional climax
Authentic, unflinching portrayal of addiction consequences

comparable_films.title: Babel
comparable_films.similarity: Multi-character drama exploring grief and connection

comparable_films.title: Manchester by the Sea
comparable_films.similarity: Male grief, family healing, similar tone

target_audience.latam_audience_notes: Family themes resonate strongly, addiction angle requires sensitive marketing

budget_tier.justification: Contemporary setting, character-driven, minimal VFX requirements

assessment.recommendation_rationale: Solid character work and authentic emotional content merit consideration, but significant development needed to address pacing, theatrical appeal, and marketing viability before greenlight.

film_now_assessment.lightning_test: Opening garage fire is visually compelling but doesn't hook until Brian's death page 27
film_now_assessment.career_risk_test: Would not stake career - too many commercial uncertainties despite quality writing
film_now_assessment.legacy_potential: Unlikely to be remembered - competent but not transcendent

analysis.verdict_statement: A well-crafted character drama with authentic emotional content that merits development consideration, but faces significant commercial and theatrical challenges that must be addressed.
analysis.executive_summary: Competent grief/addiction drama with strong character work but limited theatrical appeal. Development needed to address pacing and marketing before production consideration.
